members.member:
Implements a base class for request/response collections.
The type of the requests. The type of the responses. The type used to wrap the requests when presenting them to consumers.
A request/response collection is a thread-safe, asynchronous, bidirectional producer/consumer collection.
On one side is one or more producers which can, from any thread, add requests to the collection. After a request is added, a response is awaited.
On the other side is one or more consumers which can, from any thread, take requests from the collection. A consumer then processes a request and issues the response, causing the awaiting request to continue with that response.
Therefore, requests and responses can be two different types ( and ) to allow true bidirectional data flow from the producer to the consumer and back.
A consumer can only process one request at a time. And one request is processed by exactly one consumer.
If there are consumers waiting for requests, a new request is issued to the consumer already waiting the longest. If there are no consumers waiting for requests, a new request will be stored and issued to the next consumer which wants to take requests for processing.
Requests are presented to consumers using types deriving from (). wraps the request (available through the property) and provides methods to finish the request processing and issue a response (such as ).

members.member:
Implements a request/response queue.
The type of the requests. The type of the responses.
A request/response queue is a thread-safe, asynchronous, bidirectional producer/consumer queue.
Operations work like this: A request is put into the queue by any thread and the response is then awaited. A consumer on any thread takes requests out of the queue, processes it, and provides the response, causing the request to continue.
See and for more details.

members.member:
Defines a generic interface for priority queues.
The type of items stored in the priority queue.
A priority queue stores items sorted by their assigned priority. The priority is assigned to an item when the item is added to the priority queue using . The higher the priority, the earlier the item is dequeued (highest priority, first out). For items of the same priority, the order in which they are added is maintained (first in, first out).
null are valid item values if is a reference type.
TODO: Add support for IPriorityQueueAware

member.summary: Gets the highest priority currently in the queue.
member.value: The highest priority currently in the queue or -1 if the queue is empty.

member.name: P:RI.Utilities.Collections.Generic.IPriorityQueue`1.LowestPriority
member.summary: Gets the lowest priority currently in the queue.
member.value: The lowest priority currently in the queue or -1 if the queue is empty.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Collections.Generic.IPriorityQueue`1.Clear
member.summary: Removes all items from the priority queue.

remarks.para: This is a O(1) operation.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Collections.Generic.IPriorityQueue`1.Dequeue
member.summary: Gets the next item in the queue and removes it.
member.returns: The item.

remarks.para: This is a O(1) operation.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Collections.Generic.IPriorityQueue`1.Dequeue(System.Int32@)
member.summary: Gets the next item in the queue and removes it.
member.returns: The item.

remarks.para: This is a O(1) operation.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Collections.Generic.IPriorityQueue`1.Enqueue(`0)
member.summary: Adds an item to the queue.

remarks.para: The item is added to the queue using the lowest current priority (similar to ) or with a priority of 0 if the queue is empty. This ensures the item is inserted truly at the end of the queue.
This is a O(1) operation.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Collections.Generic.IPriorityQueue`1.Enqueue(`0,System.Int32)
member.summary: Adds an item to the queue.

remarks.para: This is a O(x) operation, where x is the number of priorities currently in use, if is currently not yet in use, or a O(1) operation if there are already other items of the same priority.

member.summary: Moves all items of this queue to another queue while keeping the assigned priorities.
member.param: The other queue the items are moved to.
member.returns: The number of moved items.

remarks.note: As the name of this method implies, the items are moved to the other queue, dequeueing all items from this queue.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Collections.Generic.IPriorityQueueExtensions.Remove``1(RI.Utilities.Collections.Generic.IPriorityQueue{``0},``0)
member.summary: Removes all occurences of an item from the priority queue. Comparison is done using the default equality comparison.
member.typeparam: The type of the items in .
member.returns: The number of times the item was removed from the priority queue.

member.name: T:RI.Utilities.Collections.Generic.PriorityQueue`1
member.summary: Implements a simple priority queue.
member.typeparam: The type of items stored in the priority queue.

remarks.para: The performance of the priority queue degrades with the number of different priorities used. Regardless of the actual numeric priority values or the distribution of the priority values respectively, a priority queue with, for example, 10 used priorities is on average 10 times faster than a priority queue with 100 used priorities.
See for more details.

member.summary: Converts a sequence to a dictionary by deriving a key from each element. Each key can be assigned to one or more elements. Key equality is checked using the default equality comparer for the key type.
member.typeparam: The type of the elements of .
The type of the derived keys in the dictionary.
The type of the values in the dictionary.
member.param: The sequence which contains the elements.
The function which derives a key and a value for each element in the sequence.
member.returns: The dictionary which contains the key-value-pairs where each value is a list of values derived from the elements which have the same key derived/assigned. The dictionary is empty if the sequence contains no elements.

remarks.para: This is a O(n^2) operation where n is the number of elements in the sequence.
is enumerated exactly once.

member.summary: Converts a sequence to a new list, starting at a specified index.
member.typeparam: The type of the elements of .
member.param: The sequence which contains the elements.
The index from which the elements are copied to the list.
member.returns: A list which contains all elements of the sequence, starting at the specified index, in the order they were enumerated. The list has a length of zero if the sequence contains no elements or the specified index is outside the sequence.

is enumerated exactly once.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Collections.IEnumerableExtensions.ToList``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts a sequence to a new list, starting at a specified index for a specified number of elements.
member.typeparam: The type of the elements of .
member.param: The sequence which contains the elements.
The index from which the elements are copied to the list.
The number of elements to copy to the list, starting at the specified index.
member.returns: A list which contains the specified number of elements of the sequence in the order they were enumerated. The list has a length of zero if the sequence contains no elements, the specified index is outside the sequence, or is zero. If the range specified by and reaches outside the sequence, the list stops at the last element of the sequence.

remarks.para: This is a O(n) operation where n is the number of elements in the sequence.
is enumerated only once and only up to the last element in the range specified by and .

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Collections.IListExtensions.Shuffle``1(System.Collections.Generic.IList{``0},System.Random,System.Int32)
member.summary: Puts all items in a list in random order.
member.typeparam: The type of the items in .
member.param: The randomizer which is used for randomizing the indices of the items.
The number of times the list is "shaked".
member.returns: The number of items put into random order.

remarks.para: The list is partially shuffled. That means that each item is moved randomly away from its original index. The more , the farther away an item might move from its original position. A of zero means that the list remains the same and no items are shuffled.

Since the behaviour of the actual type of is not known, the shuffling is not done in-place. Instead, all items are copied and then shuffled, the list cleared, and then all sorted items are added again.

member.summary: Swaps two items in a list specified by their index.
member.typeparam: The type of the items in .
member.param: The index of the first item to swap.
The index of the second item to swap.

remarks.para: The swapping is done by copying the first and second item, then replacing the first and second item with default(), and then replacing the first and second item with the swapped and copied items. Therefore, briefly during the swapping, the list does not contain the first and second item but twice default() in their place.

member.exception: or is less than zero or bigger or equal to the size of the list.

member.exception: or is less than zero or bigger or equal to the size of the list.

members.member:
Implements a list which uses data virtualization to load data (the items in the collection) on demand.
The type of items virtualized.
uses an or to load items on-demand. That means that items are only loaded when they are actually requested through (e.g. by using the collections indexer property).
Items are loaded in pages which size can be specified when constructing . The loaded pages will then stay in the cache for a specified amount of time.
If is used, will clear the entire cache.

member.name: T:RI.Utilities.Comparison.CollectionComparer`1
member.summary: Implements an for comparing collections and their elements.
member.typeparam: The type of the elements in the collections being compared for equality.

remarks.note: Two collections are considered equal if they contain the same number of elements and each element in one collection has an equal element in the other collection. The collections themselves are not compared for equality, only their elements.

This implementation of is only intended for equality comparison of elements of collections. It should not be used in scenarios where hash values of the collections themselves are used, e.g. used as a hash provider for the collections when storing the collections in another collection (e.g. storing collections in a or ).

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Comparison.CollectionComparer`1.Equals(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{`0},System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{`0})
member.summary: Determines whether two specified collections, or their elements respectively, are considered equal.
member.param: The first collection to compare with .
The second collection to compare with .
member.returns: true if the collections are considered equal, false otherwise. true is returned if both and are null. false is returned if only one of and is null.

remarks.para: and are each enumerated exactly once. and are not enumerated if both are the same reference or either one is null.
This is a O(n*m) operation if order is ignored or a O(n+m) operation if order is not ignored, where n is the number of elements in and m is the number of elements in .

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Comparison.CollectionComparer`1.System#Collections#Generic#IEqualityComparer{System#Collections#Generic#IEnumerable{T}}#GetHashCode(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{`0})
member.summary: Determines the hash value of a specified collection.
member.returns: The hash value of the collection.

remarks.para: The behaviour of this method is controlled by the presence or absence of the option.
is enumerated exactly once. is not enumerated if the hash code is taken from the collection itself.
This is a O(1) operation if the hash code is taken from the collection itself, O(n) otherwise where n is the number of items in .

member.name: F:RI.Utilities.Comparison.CollectionComparerFlags.ReferenceEquality
member.summary: Two collections are only considered equal if their elements are of the same reference, regardless of the elements own behaviour regarding equality.

member.name: F:RI.Utilities.Comparison.CollectionComparerFlags.DoNotGetHashFromElements

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Comparison.EqualityComparison`1.#ctor(System.Func{`0,`0,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Creates a new instance of .
member.param: The function which is used to compare two objects of type .

remarks.para: The created with this constructor uses the objects (of type ) own method for calculating hash values.

Therefore, the created with this constructor should not be used in scenarios where hash values are used, e.g. as the equality comparer of a or , if the hash value calculation of the objects own method does not correspond to the equality comparison performed by . If those do not correspond but it is still used for hash values, performance might be severly impacted or, depending on the usage of the hash values, other strange side-effects might occur.

member.name: T:RI.Utilities.DataFormats.Csv.CsvDocument
member.summary: Contains and manages structured CSV data.

remarks.para: CSV data in a is stored in the property. is always kept up to date and all actions performed on an directly read from or modify .

is organized as a list containing lists of strings in a sequential order (e.g. as they would appear in a CSV file). The outer list represent rows while the inner lists represent columns (all columns of one row per inner list).
can be modified arbitrarily by either using methods of or by modifying the list itself. The list can contain or be modified to contain any sequence of strings.

CSV data is organized in rows and columns where the data is usually used and organized row-by-row. Each row can have an arbitrary length of columns, therefore the number of columns can vary from row to row.
There are zero, one, or more rows. Empty data is interpreted as having no rows (and therefore no columns) while data consisting only of whitespaces is considered having one row with one column.
A row has zero, one, or more columns. An empty line is interpreted as having no columns while a line consisting only of whitespaces is considered having one column.
A value is a specific column of a specific row (sometimes also called cells).
Values are sperated by a separator character (see ).
Rows are separated by carriage-returns (CR) and line-feeds (LF), depending on the environment.
A value are enclosed in quotes ( " ) if the value itself consists of multiple lines or the value itslef contains quotes.

For multiline values, the carriage-return (CR) / line-feed (LF) does not represent a row separator. It is merely the same logical CSV row which spans multiple textual rows where the quote is used to detect that the carriage-return/line-feed belongs to the value and is not a row separator (because it occurs inside a quoted block).
Each quote contained in a value is written using twice the quote character. For example, the value Test"123 is written as "Test""123" and ""Hello is written as """""Hello" .

remarks.para: If is null, the values are added outside a section (that is: before the first section header or at the end if no section header exists).
is ignored if is null, the behavior of is applied.
If is empty, an empty section is added anyways (consisting only of the section header).
All values in will be added, even if a name-value-pair with the same name already exists.
This method is used if the dictionary can have only one value per name-value-pair.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.DataFormats.Ini.IniDocument.GetSection(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the name-value-pairs of a section as a dictionary.
member.returns: The dictionary which contains the name-value-pairs of the specified section or null if the specified section does not exist. An empty dictionary is returned if the section exists but does not contain any name-value-pairs.

remarks.para: If is null, all values outside a section are returned (that is: before the first section header or all if no section header exists).
The returned dictionary uses .

If the specified section exists multiple times, only the first section is returned as a dictionary. If the same name-value-pair exists multiple times in a section, only the first pair is returned in the dictionary.

remarks.para: If is null, all values outside a section are returned (that is: before the first section header or all if no section header exists).
The returned dictionary uses .

If the specified section exists multiple times, only the first section is returned as a dictionary. If the same name-value-pair exists multiple times in a section, all pairs are returned in the dictionary (using the inner list).

member.summary: Gets the name-value-pairs of a section as dictionaries.
member.returns: The list which contains all the dictionaries which contain the name-value-pairs of the specified section or null if the specified section does not exist. An empty list is returned if the section exists but does not contain any name-value-pairs.

remarks.para: If is null, all values outside a section are returned (that is: before the first section header or all if no section header exists). In that case, the returned list contains only one dictionary.
The returned dictionary uses .

The returned list contains a separate dictionary for each separate section of the specified name. If the same name-value-pair exists multiple times in a section, only the first pair is returned in the corresponding dictionary.

member.summary: Sets the value of a specified name in a specified section.
member.param: The name of the section (can be null).
The value or null if the value should be removed (similar to ).

remarks.para: The first matching value of the first matching section is set, all other matching values are removed. If is null, the value is set outside any section.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.DataFormats.Ini.IniWriter.Finalize
member.summary: Garbage collects this instance of .

member.name: P:RI.Utilities.DataFormats.Ini.IniWriter.BaseWriter
member.summary: Gets the which is used by this INI writer to write the INI data.
member.value: The which is used by this INI writer to write the INI data or null if the the INI writer is closed/disposed.

member.name: P:RI.Utilities.DataFormats.Ini.IniWriter.Settings
member.summary: Gets the used writer settings for this INI writer.
member.value: The used writer settings for this INI writer.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.DataFormats.Ini.IniWriter.Close
member.summary: Closes this INI writer and its underlying ().

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.DataFormats.Ini.IniWriter.Flush
member.summary: Flushes all written data to the underlying ().
member.exception: The INI writer has been closed/disposed.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.DataFormats.Ini.IniWriter.WriteComment(System.String)
member.summary: Writes a comment.

remarks.para: The comment will not be encoded but if it contains multiple lines, multiple actual comments will be written (one per line).
If is null or an empty string, an empty string is written as comment.

member.exception: The INI writer has been closed/disposed.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.DataFormats.Ini.IniWriter.WriteElement(RI.Utilities.DataFormats.Ini.IniElement)
member.summary: Writes an INI element.
member.exception: The INI writer has been closed/disposed.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.DataFormats.Ini.IniWriter.WriteSection(System.String)
member.summary: Writes a section header.

remarks.para: The written section name will be encoded which means that certain special characters used in INI files will be replaced with escape sequences. See for more details.

member.exception: The INI writer has been closed/disposed.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.DataFormats.Ini.IniWriter.WriteText(System.String)
member.summary: Writes arbitrary text.

remarks.para: The text will not be encoded but if it contains multiple lines, multiple actual text lines will be written.
If is null or an empty string, an empty string is written as text.

member.exception: The INI writer has been closed/disposed.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.DataFormats.Ini.IniWriter.WriteValue(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Writes a name-value-pair.

remarks.para: The written name and value will be encoded which means that certain special characters used in INI files will be replaced with escape sequences. See for more details.
If is null or an empty string, an empty string is written as value.

member.exception: The INI writer has been closed/disposed.

member.name: T:RI.Utilities.DataFormats.Ini.IniWriterSettings
member.summary: Provides INI writer settings.

remarks.para: INI writer settings can be used to customize how INI data is generated and formated.
See for more general and detailed information about working with INI data.

member.name: F:RI.Utilities.DataFormats.Ini.IniWriterSettings.DefaultEmptyLineBeforeSectionHeader
member.summary: The default whether an additional new line is written before a section header.

remarks.para: The default value is false.

member.name: P:RI.Utilities.DataFormats.Ini.IniWriterSettings.EmptyLineBeforeSectionHeader
member.summary: Gets or sets whether an additional new line is written before a section header.
member.value: true if an additional new line is written before a section header, false otherwise.

remarks.para: The default value is .

member.summary: Converts a date and time into a sortable string.
member.returns: The date and time as a sortable string in the following format yyyyMMddHHmmssfff with no separator between the units. Example: 20160201143050333

member.summary: Provides utility/extension methods for the type.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Globalization.CultureInfoExtensions.EqualsLanguage(System.Globalization.CultureInfo,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Determines whether two cultures have the same language.
member.returns: true if the two cultures have the same language, false otherwise.

remarks.para: Two cultures are considered language-equal if the have the same language part. For example, en-US is language-equal to en or en-GB , but not to de-DE or fr .

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Numbers.DoubleExtensions.GetValueOrDefault(System.Double)
member.summary: Gets the number or the default value (0.0) if a double precision floating point number is "NaN"/"Not-a-Number" or infinity (positive or negative).
member.param: The double precision floating point number.
member.returns: Zero if the number is "NaN"/"Not-a-Number" or infinity (either positive or negative), otherwise.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Numbers.DoubleExtensions.GetValueOrDefault(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Gets the number or a specified default value if a double precision floating point number is "NaN"/"Not-a-Number" or infinity (positive or negative).
member.param: The double precision floating point number.
The value to return when is "NaN"/"Not-a-Number" or infinity.
member.returns: if the number is "NaN"/"Not-a-Number" or infinity (either positive or negative), otherwise.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Numbers.DoubleExtensions.IsInfinity(System.Double)
member.summary: Determines whether a double precision floating point number is infinity (positive or negative).
member.param: The double precision floating point number.
member.returns: true if the number is infinity (either positive or negative), false otherwise.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Numbers.DoubleExtensions.IsNan(System.Double)
member.summary: Determines whether a double precision floating point number is "NaN"/"Not-a-Number".
member.param: The double precision floating point number.
member.returns: true if the number is "NaN"/"Not-a-Number", false otherwise.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Numbers.DoubleExtensions.IsNanOrInfinity(System.Double)
member.summary: Determines whether a double precision floating point number is "NaN"/"Not-a-Number" or infinity (positive or negative).
member.param: The double precision floating point number.
member.returns: true if the number is "NaN"/"Not-a-Number" or infinity (either positive or negative), false otherwise.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Numbers.DoubleExtensions.IsNumber(System.Double)
member.summary: Determines whether a double precision floating point number is neither "NaN"/"Not-a-Number" nor infinity (positive or negative).
member.param: The double precision floating point number.
member.returns: true if the number is neither "NaN"/"Not-a-Number" nor infinity (either positive or negative) but rather a real number, false otherwise.

member.param: The single precision floating point number.
The value to return when is "NaN"/"Not-a-Number" or infinity.
member.returns: if the number is "NaN"/"Not-a-Number" or infinity (either positive or negative), otherwise.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Numbers.FloatExtensions.IsInfinity(System.Single)
member.summary: Determines whether a single precision floating point number is infinity (positive or negative).
member.param: The single precision floating point number.
member.returns: true if the number is infinity (either positive or negative), false otherwise.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Numbers.FloatExtensions.IsNan(System.Single)
member.summary: Determines whether a single precision floating point number is "NaN"/"Not-a-Number".
member.param: The single precision floating point number.
member.returns: true if the number is "NaN"/"Not-a-Number", false otherwise.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Numbers.FloatExtensions.IsNanOrInfinity(System.Single)
member.summary: Determines whether a single precision floating point number is "NaN"/"Not-a-Number" or infinity (positive or negative).
member.param: The single precision floating point number.
member.returns: true if the number is "NaN"/"Not-a-Number" or infinity (either positive or negative), false otherwise.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Numbers.FloatExtensions.IsNumber(System.Single)
member.summary: Determines whether a single precision floating point number is neither "NaN"/"Not-a-Number" nor infinity (positive or negative).
member.param: The single precision floating point number.
member.returns: true if the number is neither "NaN"/"Not-a-Number" nor infinity (either positive or negative) but rather a real number, false otherwise.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Numbers.NumberExtensions.Magnitude(System.SByte)
member.summary: Calculates the magnitude of a value.
member.returns: The magnitude.

remarks.para: The magnitude expresses the order of magnitude of a number. Simply said, it calculates the number of significant digits on the left side of the decimal point.
If is positive, the result is positive. If is negative, the result is negative. If is zero, the result is zero.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Numbers.NumberExtensions.DivRem(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Gets the remainder of a division.
member.returns: The remainder of dividend / divisor.

remarks.note: This is not the same as simply applying the module operator. The remainder is calculated, allowing the operation for floating point values.

member.name: T:RI.Utilities.Numbers.RomanNumber
member.summary: Type to convert and/or store roman numbers.

remarks.para: You can either use to store a roman number by creating instances of it or use its static methods to convert from/to roman numbers.
See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roman_numerals for details about roman numbers.
Only the uppercase letters I (1), V (5), X (10), L (50), C (100), D (500), M (1000) are supported, lowercase letters of those characters are considered invalid (as is any other character).
When converting from roman to decimal, additive and subtractive forms are supported. When converting from decimal to roman, the subtractive form is used for certain special cases (see below).
The following special cases represent numbers in subtractive form (only these are supported): IV (4), IX (9), XL (40), XC (90), CD (400), CM (900).

Both positive and negative numbers are supported as well as zero. For positive values, and will never add the plus sign as a prefix but parsed values (, , ) can have an optional plus sign prefix. For negative values, both roman and decimal representations use a minus sign prefix. An empty string is used to express zero.
remarks.note: Apostrophus and Vinculum are not supported for larger numbers. Therefore, the value 1'000'000'000 would result in one million M s. It is advised that the numbers are clamped to a reasonable range which is suitable for you.

members.member:
Describes a path to a directory.
uses to extract and store path information. See for more details about the supported types of directory paths.
provides more directory path specific functionalities compared to and offers a more consistent way of working with paths than . It can be implicitly converted to a to work seamless with APIs using for paths.
See for possible format strings for .
See for an example how to use and .
// see FilePath for examples

member.name: T:RI.Utilities.Paths.PathProperties
member.summary: Describes a path and its properties.

remarks.para: analyzes a path and contains, besides the path itself, several properties which describe the characteristics of the path. For invalid paths, an error description is provided ().
supports Windows, Unix, and UNC style paths.
supports the following format strings; o, O, g, G, null or empty string: The original path () / n, N: The normalized path () / r, R: The resolved path ().

member.name: F:RI.Utilities.Paths.PathProperties.FileExtensionSeparator
member.summary: The separator character between a file name and its extension.

member.name: F:RI.Utilities.Paths.PathProperties.RelativeUp
member.summary: The string which can be used as a relative directory name to point one level upwards.

member.summary: The wildcard character which is a placeholder for exactly one characters.

members.member:
Provides a utility which allows dynamic dispatching of method calls based on a parameters type.
Method call dispatching is the dynamic forwarding of a method call based on the name of methods (including overloads) and the type of the first method parameter.
A can be created either for an object or a type. If an object is used, the method calls are forwarded to the instance methods of that object. If a type is used, the method calls are forwarded to the static methods of the type.
First, an instance of is created using or . Afterwards, calls to the methods or the overloads respectively, as specified by the methods name, can be dispatched. This is done by checking which method overload (if any) has a first parameter which matches the dispatched parameters type. That method is then called.
TODO: Add support for multiple parameters (requires utility to find best matching types based on type enumerables)

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Reflection.MethodCallDispatcher.FromTarget(System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a method call dispatcher for a specified object.
member.param: The name of the methods the calls are dispatched to.
member.returns: A new instance of .

remarks.para: Only instance methods are considered for dispatching when using an object instead of a type.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Reflection.MethodCallDispatcher.FromType(System.Type,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a method call dispatcher for a specified type.
member.param: The name of the methods the calls are dispatched to.
member.returns: A new instance of .

remarks.para: Only static methods are considered for dispatching when using a type instead of an object.

member.value: The name of the methods the calls are dispatched to.

member.name: T:RI.Utilities.Streams.LoopbackStream
member.summary: Implements a stream where write operations are written to a queue and read operations read from that queue.

remarks.para: Bytes written using or are written to a queue. When bytes are read using or , the bytes are read from that queue. The queue is using first-in first-out (FIFO), meaning that bytes written first are read first.

is thread-safe. One thread can write to the strem while another thread can read from the stream at the same time. However, only one read and only one write operation can be performed at the same time. Calling a read or write operation while another is already in progress, the call blocks.
Timeouts are supported. When a greater than zero is used, read operations will wait for the specified amount of time if the queue is empty. can be used but is ignored by .

members.member:
Implements a stream which wraps another stream and synchronizes access to it using a synchronization object.
can be used to synchronize access to a stream from multiple threads.
Only the access to members are synchronized. Repeated access (e.g. a followed by a ), which rely on to be of atomic nature, must be synchronized on a higher level, by the users of , using .

remarks.para: can be helpful in situations where you pass a stream to an object or method which, after it has done its job, closes the stream and you need the stream still open afterwards.

member.name: T:RI.Utilities.Text.AlphanumComparer
member.summary: Implements a comparer which uses natural alphanumeric string sorting.

remarks.para: Natural alphanumeric sorting is a more sophisticated string sorting algorithm which respects the natural way humans look at strings, especially if they contain numbers.

The following list of strings is used as an example: Test100xyz, Test200abc, Test99abc. Traditional sorting would sort this list as shown, putting Test99abc at the end (because the first four characters are the same and then 9 is greater than 2). With natural alphanumeric sorting, the list is sorted as: Test99abc, Test100xyz, Test200abc (because the algorithm builds chunks and compares those instead of character-by-character).
Because this kind of sorting depends on the used culture, the used culture must be specified.

members.member:
Used to parse and/or build command line strings including executable, parameters, and/or literals.
A command line consists of the following: [executable] [parameter 1 [parameter 2] ... [parameter n]] [literal 1 [literal 2] ... [literal n]].
Example 1: myprogram.exe -name1=value1 literal1 literal2
Example 2: "d:\my folder\my program.exe" -name1="Some value with whitespace and \"quotes\"" SomeLiteral "Another literal"
A command line can have: Zero or one executable. Zero, one, or multiple parameters. Zero, one, or multiple literals.
If an executable is used, it is always at the beginning of the command line. An executable supports whitespaces when wrapped in quotes.
Parameters are always name/value pairs which start with a minus sign and which separates the name and the value with an equal sign. A parameter name and value supports whitespaces and quotes when wrapped in quotes, where the quotes need to be escaped. Note that parameters can also consist of only the name, e.g. -name , without the equal sign or any value.
Literals are just a list of strings (e.g. a list of files). A literal supports whitespaces and quotes when wrapped in quotes, where the quotes need to be escaped.
When parsing command lines, the order of parameters and literals does not matter, they can be mixed as needed.
TODO: Implement IEquatable TODO: Implement IComparable TODO: Implement IFormattable TODO: Make serializable

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Text.CommandLine.Parse(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Parses a command line string and returns a object for it.
member.param: The command line string to parse.
Indicates whether the command line string starts with an executable.
member.returns: The created by parsing the command line string.

remarks.para: No deep error checking is performed on the parsed command line string so any string can be parsed and is considered a valid command line. Invalid command lines will result in strange content of the .

Because an executable cannot be distinguished from a literal, it must be specified whether the command line string starts with an executable. For example, on Windows, a full process command line (e.g. as retrieved using ) usually starts with the executable of the process.
is used to distinguish parameter names.

remarks.para: No deep error checking is performed on the parsed command line string so any string can be parsed and is considered a valid command line. Invalid command lines will result in strange content of the .

member.name: P:RI.Utilities.Text.CommandLine.Parameters
member.summary: Gets the dictionary of parameters of the command line.
member.value: The dictionary of parameters of the command line.
member.remarks: The dictionary keys are the parameter names. The dictionary values are lists of parameter values for the associated parameter name. Therefore, a parameter name can have multiple parameter values.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Text.CommandLine.Build
member.summary: Builds the command line string corresponding to the data of this command line.
member.returns: The built command line string.

remarks.para: If this command line is "empty" (means: contains no executable, parameters, or literals), the resulting command line string is an empty string of zero length.

If an executable is used, it is placed at the beginning of the command line string. The executable is wrapped in quotes if it contains any whitespaces. If the executable is null, a string of zero length, or contains only whitespaces, the executable is omited.

Parameters are always added after the executable, before the literals. Parameter names and values are wrapped in quotes if they are of zero length, contain any whitespaces, or contain quotes. Parameter values which are null are omited. If a parameter has no associated values (means: the corresponding list of values in the dictionary contains no values or only null), a single parameter of the corresponding name but without a value is created.
Literals are always added after the parameters. Literals are wrapped in quotes if they are of zero length, contain any whitespaces, or contain quotes. Literals which are null are omited.

The of the cloned command line is also cloned if it implements or .

member.summary: A which encapsulates another so that it can be used with auto-indentation.

remarks.para: Auto-indentation means that each line written to the encapsulated starts with a defined indentation.

member.name: T:RI.Utilities.Text.StringExtensions
member.summary: Provides utility/extension methods for the type.

remarks.para: Note that some of the functionality provided by this class is rather specialized and intended to be used for certain string parsing/processing purposes.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Text.StringExtensions.Contains(System.String,System.String,System.StringComparison)
member.summary: Determines whether a specified string occurs in a string.
member.param: The string to find in the string.
The string comparison used to find the string.
member.returns: true if is an empty string or it occurs at least once in the string, false otherwise.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Text.StringExtensions.ContainsWhitespace(System.String)
member.summary: Determines whether a specified string contains any whitespace characters.
member.returns: true if the string contains any whistespace characters, false otherwise. If the string has a length of zero, false is returned.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Text.StringExtensions.DoubleOccurrence(System.String,System.Char)
member.summary: Doubles each occurence of a specified character in a string.
member.param: The character of which each occurence is doubled.
member.returns: The resulting string with each specified character occurence doubled.

remarks.para: Doubling occurrences is done on a per-character basis and case-sensitive.
For example, when doubling the occurence for 'A', the string "" results in "", "A" in "AA", "AA" in "AAAA", "ABC" in "AABC", etc.
This is the same as using with a factor of 2.0 and offset of 0.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Text.StringExtensions.EndsWithCount(System.String,System.Char,System.StringComparison)
member.summary: Counts how many times a string ends with a specified character.
member.param: The character to count when occuring at the end of the string.
The string comparison used to find the character.
member.returns: The number of times the specified character appears in succession at the end of the string.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Text.StringExtensions.EndsWithCount(System.String,System.String,System.StringComparison)
member.summary: Counts how many times a string ends with a specified string.
member.param: The string to count when occuring at the end of the string.
The string comparison used to find the string.
member.returns: The number of times the specified string appears in succession at the end of the string.
member.exception: is a string with zero length.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Text.StringExtensions.Escape(System.String,RI.Utilities.Text.StringEscapeOptions)
member.summary: Converts a string into another string where certain special characters are converted to escape sequences.
member.returns: The resulting string with special characters converted to escape sequences.

remarks.para: An escape sequence always starts with \ followed by a single character specifying the escape sequence, e.g. \n for new-line.
The following special characters are escaped: \a, \b, \f, \n, \r, \t, \v, \, ', ".

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Text.StringExtensions.HalveOccurrence(System.String,System.Char)
member.summary: Halves each occurence of a specified character in a string.
member.param: The character of which each occurence is halved.
member.returns: The resulting string with each specified character occurrence halved.

remarks.para: Halving occurrences is done on a per-character basis and case-sensitive.
For example, when halving the occurence for 'A', the string "" results in "", "A" in "", "AA" results in "A", "AAA" in "A", "AAAA" in "AA", "ABC" in "BC", etc.
This is the same as using with a factor of 0.5 and offset of 0.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Text.StringExtensions.ModifyOccurrence(System.String,System.Char,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Modifies each occurence of a specified character in a string by a specified factor and/or offset.
member.param: The character of which each occurence is modified.
The factor used by which each occurence is modified.
The offset used by which each occurence is modified.
member.returns: The resulting string with each specified character occurence modified.

remarks.para: Modifying occurrences is done on a per-character basis and case-sensitive.

Example with of 3.0 and of 0 for the character 'A': "" -> "", "A" -> "AAA", "AA" -> "AAAAAA", "AAA" -> "AAAAAAAAA", "ABC" -> "AAABC", etc. Example with of 0.0 and of 1 for the character 'A': "" -> "", "A" -> "AA", "AA" -> "AAA", "AAAA" -> "AAAAA", "ABC" -> "AABC", etc.
If and are both used ( not 1.0 and not 0), the resulting character count is ((original count * ) + ).

member.exception: is "NaN"/"Not-a-Number" or infinity (either positive or negative).

member.returns: The resulting string with the repeated string. If is zero, the resulting string has a length of zero. If is one, the resulting string consists only of the specified string.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Text.StringExtensions.ReplaceSingleStart(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.StringComparison)
member.summary: Searchs a specified token in a string and replaces its occurence with a specified replacement, but only if the last character in the string, before a found token begins, is not the same as the first character of the specified token.
member.param: The token to find and replace.
The replacement for each found token.
The string comparison used to find the token.
member.returns: The resulting string where each token is replaced by the replacement.

remarks.para: The replacement only happens if the character before a found token is not the same as the first character of the token. For example, when using "|x" as token and "X" as replacement, the string "ab|xcd" becomes "abXcd" but the string "ab||xcd" remains unchanged.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Text.StringExtensions.Unescape(System.String,RI.Utilities.Text.StringEscapeOptions)
member.summary: Converts a string into another string where escape sequences are converted back to certain special characters.
member.returns: The resulting string with escape sequences converted back to special characters.

remarks.para: An escape sequence always starts with \ followed by a single character specifying the escape sequence, e.g. \n for new-line.
The following special characters are un-escaped: \a, \b, \f, \n, \r, \t, \v, \, ', ".

member.name: T:RI.Utilities.Text.StringSplitPredicate
member.summary: Defines a delegate which can be used with the . and . method to implement custom splitting of strings by testing between each character of the string whether it is a split position.
member.param: The whole string which is being splitted.
The current token, which is the string starting at the last split position up to and including the index specified by .
The index of the previous character.
The index of the next character.
member.returns: true if a split position between and has been found.

remarks.para: Split testing always happens between characters so that when a split position is found (the return value of is true), the character at the index goes into the previous token while the character at the index goes into the next token.

is called before the first character, between each following character, and after the last character of a string to test whether to split the string at that position. Therefore, before the first character, is -1 and is 0, after the first character is 0 and is 1, and so forth, and after the last character is n-1 and is n where n is the length of the string.

member.name: T:RI.Utilities.Text.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: Contains utilities and extensions for working with text data and I/O.

members.member:
Implements a heavy-weight thread which encapsulates thread setup and execution and also captures exceptions.
is usually used for long-running and/or dedicated threads where a higher control and encapsulation of the threads execution is required, e.g. compared to .
See and for a description of the thread execution sequence.
Some virtual methods are called from within locks to . Be careful in inheriting classes when calling outside code from those methods (e.g. through events, callbacks, or other virtual methods) to not produce deadlocks!
TODO: OnStopped TODO: HeavyThreadAwaiter (incl. option for thread configuration callback)

member.name: P:RI.Utilities.Threading.HeavyThread.HasStoppedGracefully
member.summary: Gets whether the thread has gracefully stopped without exception.
member.value: true if the thread stopped gracefully and had no exception, false if the thread was forcibly terminated (due to timeout) and/or had an exception, or null if the thread was not started or is still running.

item.para: is waiting until finishes inside or the timeout specified by occurs.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Threading.HeavyThread.Stop
member.summary: Stops the thread and frees all resources.

remarks.para: The stop sequence goes as follows:

item.para: is set to true. is signaled. All stop tasks, added by , are completed.
waits until ended ( and finished executing inside ) or the timeout specified by occurs.
If did not end on its own so a timeout occurred (see step above), the thread is terminated using .

remarks.note: The thread cannot be stopped from inside itself (e.g. you cannot call from , , or ). This means that the eventual stop has to be controlled by the owner of . This ensures symmetry of start/stop (only who can start can also stop it).

member.exception: This function was called from inside the thread.

member.summary: Adds a to this thread which is completed when the thread is requested to stop.

remarks.para: A task can be added multiple times but will only be completed once.
All added tasks will be completed using by . Therefore, no tasks added after was called will be completed.

member.summary: Called when the thread begins execution.

This method is called from the thread.

member.name: M:RI.Utilities.Threading.HeavyThread.OnEnd
member.summary: Called when the thread ends execution.

remarks.para: This method is intended for on-thread cleanup of the threads operation. The thread ends as soon as returns. See and for more details.
remarks.note: This method is called from the thread.
Under very rare circumstances, this method is called twice. Therefore, overrides of this method must be designed accordingly.
